dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see flashes of memory. A balloon in trouble. A man * falling. * Glints of sunlight through an ominous grey sky. * AMELIA WREN, late 20s with a hazardous expression, sits behind the window of a fast moving carriage. She’s lookin at the sky - and there’s pain mirrored in her eyes. *

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Stop the carriage. She bangs hard on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop the carriage. The carriage is pulled to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMELIA gets out of the carriage - she tumbles out in her to dismount with speed. She stands on the dirty street. S tries to recover her composure. ANTONIA, her caring siste gets out of the carriage behind her. On-screen title: LONDON, 1862. *

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: Amelia, are you quite well? AMELIA looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t need to fly today. Return to Richmond with me...

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Antonia, I just need a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: With all you've been through... No- one would think worse of you....

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I would. I would think worse of me. * I made an agreement with Mr * Glaisher. *

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: You barely know the man! And the *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: little you do know, you’re irritated by. *  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 3

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Antonia, please, just give me a moment. ANTONIA frowns and nods.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: Last piece of sisterly advice - doubt is there to be listened to. She re-enters the carriage. AMELIA looks up at the sky. She thinks. She lies back on pavement, she takes a moment. A man walks by and tuts disapprovingly, but AMELIA doesn’ care. She looks up, ever up, and then she smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TITLES OVER
dialogues.text: Behind AMELIA, in the back of shot, we see A BOY RUNNING ALONG THE STREET.

dialogues.speaker: TITLES CONTINUE
dialogues.text: And now we’re with the 9 year old, a boot black in unifor as he runs, this is CHARLIE. He runs alongside dilapidate slum terraced houses. He has a look of intensity on his f He approaches an intersection of busy streets. Filled wit carts, carriages, cows and horses. He runs straight acros causing a carriage and a cart to take evasive action.

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN
dialogues.text: oi! CHARLIE stops and turns, he dances this way and then danc that. A smile on his face. COACHMAN (CONT’D) You little... CHARLIE runs on. On the other side of the road, he runs alongside a long q of people beside a wooden fence. He runs through and past them all. He sees what he’s look for - a big sign ‘HISTORY MADE. HERE. TODAY. HOW HIGH CAN THEY GO?” Above the sign sits a painted picture of a gas balloon.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 4

dialogues.speaker: TICKET TOUT
dialogues.text: The Widow Wren takes to the skies to break the world record. Get your tickets! Next to the sign is a tall hedgerow. CHARLIE checks that not being watched, and then he ducks down through a gap i the hedge, pushes through a hole in the fence behind, and sneaks into the Gardens.

dialogues.speaker: TITLES CONTINUE
dialogues.text: Everywhere there are hordes of people - all moving in one direction. There’s an air of anticipation and the chatter excitement. CHARLIE weaves and dodges, passing food sellers, Waveswingers, Revolving Chairs and Merry-Go-Rounds - stal and entertainment all put on to make the most of the occa (and maximize the money taken). But CHARLIE runs through all, determined. Until he gets to the only thing he wants to see - the onl thing everyone wants to see - he looks up in awe towards: An enormous red and white striped, silk air balloon. Bigg better, bolder than the picture on the sign. 93,000 cubic feet, 80 feet tall, and 55 feet wide, covere a vast rope webbing... It towers over the top of the fair This is the MAMMOTH. It is unlike any gas balloon you’ve seen. And it is magnificent. Charlie’s mouth gapes open, and then he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: THE AERONAUTS
dialogues.text: And we travel past CHARLIE, towards the balloon, it rests the centre of an amphitheatre type structure, filled with VAST CROWDS that have gathered to see the balloon rise. Around the circumference of the balloon, 16 men hold guid ropes to keep the Mammoth in place, with further ropes ti to stakes in the earth. The basket has a temporary platfo surrounding it.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We settle on a man in the basket of the balloon stowing a series of instruments and trying to ignore the fact that is at the centre of all the attention. This is JAMES GLAISHER, 35, a man whose forensic attention to detail be the adventurer within. He looks at his pocket watch, irritated, and then checks rechecks that the bindings on one of his barometers are securely fastened - a job he’s clearly done a hundred tim already this morning. Another man, JOHN TREW, bookish and loyal, ascends the temporary wooden steps to the platform.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: She's late.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: She is, but that is the least of your problems.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: We'll lose the light...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: James, do the clouds not look ominous to you? But JAMES doesn’t look at the clouds, he’s consumed, he climbs out of the basket and checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I repeatedly explained the importance of catching the right light and the right wind at the right time and - JAMES turns to his bag, he begins to check further instruments inside. Amongst them we see a compass, two thermometers (a “dry” and a “wet” one, which is wrapped i muslin and submerged in water), a spectroscope, a magnet, barometer, and a hygrometer.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: James. Look up. JAMES looks up. He sees the dark clouds, he frowns.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Not a concern, John, the readings I took this morning were quite clear that...  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 He bends to another basket. He puts some feed into it. pigeons inside coo appreciatively.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: Far be it from me to doubt you, but your weather predictions have been wrong in the past and it’s just possible...

dialogues.speaker: NED, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don’t even think of it. The NED is a tall bald man with a dour face. JAMES looks at h and smiles to mask a grimace.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Ned Chambers, John Trew, my very good friend. John this is Ned, one of the hardy entrepreneurs who has invested in our expedition - JOHN leans down from the platform to shake NED’s hand. Bu NED pays him no attention, he ascends the stairs to the platform, looming over JAMES ominously.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Don’t even think of telling me flight is not possible.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: Mr Chambers, we are scientists of the air, and we can tell you the one thing no-one can control is - well - the air -

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I have paid for gas, I have paid for silk - and is this balloon not the strongest and largest that’s ever been?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: But even so it can’t fight the weather, you do not want to be responsible for a tragedy, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I don’t wish to be responsible for refunding the ten thousand who've come here ‘cause you promised them history and -—

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: (cutting in) We'll fly, Ned. We’ll fly.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 7 JOHN TREW looks at his friend concerned, NED smiles. JAME GLAISHER meets eyes with NED.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We only need the sky to hold for ninety minutes - once we’re above the cloud line, it will be fine.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Good. That's fixed. Now - did you not promise me a five o’clock ascent?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I did. I am merely waiting for the pilot. It’s not the first time she's kept me waiting. NED smiles and walks away through the crowds. JAMES watch him go and then looks up anxiously at the clouds.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: What a truly pleasant man - JAMES - deliberately not looking up - starts to load a se of sample jars into the balloon, wrapping each one in cot and then placing them into the case.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: One must make compromises in order to achieve greatness my friend.... He hears a ROAR from the crowds, he turns towards it, as JAMES.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And he’s merely one compromise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fast approaching, standing on top of a carriage drawn by horses - getting cheers from all sides - AMELIA is now resplendent in a dress festooned with feathers. It’s a complete transformation from the woman we saw earlier, th woman almost cowed by the world is now wild and fabulous. has the crowd in the palm of her hand and has a look of u delight on her face. As the carriage pulls alongside the balloon, one of the m holding the ropes passes one to her. She SWINGS from it o the rostrum. She does a cartwheel on landing, and turns t cartwheel into a flip. She lands, and presents to the cro

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: You're incredibly late.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 8

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Lesson number one of Aeronauting- we are creatures of the skies and have no respect for landlocked clocks. She walks around to the steps leading to the basket, and speaks loud enough for everyone to hear her.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Glaisher, are you really not a gentlemen at all? Hold out your hand to me. JAMES holds out his hand. She takes it. And then she tumb from the steps into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Naughty. The crowd cheers. NED pushes through the crowd to see her, AMELIA smiles at beguilingly.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Are you ready?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Mr Glaisher, you have no conception of how ready I am. NED smiles at her shyly. She gets into the basket with a flourish, and then waves to the crowds. She whistles -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and jumping from the carriage window comes a dog in a s coat. She holds out her hands, he jumps into her arms.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: No. Absolutely not. Under no circumstances are we taking a dog.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I told you we’d need to put ona show for takeoff, and the crowd prefers my dog to your boxes. She indicates the scientific instruments being loaded int the balloon.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: These are essential meteorological instruments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 9 AMELIA makes eyes at one of the men holding the balloon d they nod at her authoritatively, she nods back.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: And this is an essential dog. She’s called Posey. The essential Posey. She puts Posey down, and he enters the basket through a little opening in the side. The crowd cheer. JAMES grimaces. She pulls herself from his arms onto the edge of the ball She balances along the edge, all nimble beautiful energy. raises her hands in the air. The crowd whoop. She is astonishing. She raises her hands again for silence.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen. Today myself - Amelia Wren - my naughty scientist Mr. Glaisher - and my wonder dog Posey - are going to change the world. Are you ready for us to do so? There are loud cheers.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This balloon on which I stand - the Mammoth - is a balloon like no other and will allow us to ascend higher into the air than any man or woman has ever gone. She raises her hands in the air. The crowd laugh and chee again. She looks out in the crowd and sees a man she recognises: PIERRE. She looks at him a moment and then controls herself.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The French rose to 23,000 feet. Today, we will break their record and reclaim it for these fair shores. Who knows, we may reach the moon and bring back star dust! (beat) Today is a day when history will be made - and you will all be part of it. (to Glaisher) Mr Glaisher, now’s your moment. Up you get. There are yet more cheers. AMELIA pulls JAMES upwards, so too balances on the basket. AMELIA raises both her hands the air. On cue, FIREWORKS go off around the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 10 Brilliant sparkling eruptions of colour surround the amphitheatre. The crowd ROAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAMES looks around at them all - a bemused smile on his f whilst AMELIA quickly and efficiently checks the rigging valves surrounding the basket.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Fireworks?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Are you ready?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I just need to retake my ground readings and then a final check of the equipment.... She counts the sand bags, she checks the appendix and fin she checks the valve line. She’s fast, precise and magnificently efficient.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Well, my equipment was all prepared in advance. Now, don’t touch that rope, Mr Glaisher - it’1ll let out the gas.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I do know how a balloon works. She signals to the men on the ground - who let go of the ropes and kick out the stakes.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: We fly.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Ground readings are essential - if they’re not accurate, then everything I take from now on - The balloon rises up. JAMES looks around, slightly bewildered, he starts desperately to take temperature and pressure readings.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: The sky awaits. AMELIA takes a handful of sand and deposits it off the si of the balloon which falls to the floor beneath.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 11 There’s a moment of stasis and then - with a jerk and a c or two - the balloon begins to rise up. Slowly at first, with gathering speed. It’s majestic.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: God speed, old man. JOHN TREW calls up to the basket. But JAMES GLAISHER does even notice him, he’s too intent on getting his notations down. The crowd watch in wonderment as the Mammoth silently ascends. Amongst them we pick out the face of CHARLIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 400ft. Rising 400ft/min. 25C / 77F AMELIA has a business-like air that we haven’t seen befor She pulls herself up onto the netting on the side of the balloon.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Giving the people their money's worth. She leans out and waves, the crowd cheer. The balloon ris to sixty feet and then a hundred. THOUSANDS OF PEOPLE wat from below, all with their faces turned upward to the sky She climbs further up the side of the balloon.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Won’t you damage the integrity of the balloon?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Perhaps. She pulls a cord on the side of her dress and the feather fall from it from all sides leaving her half the size.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: This is insane. The feathers twinkle down in the wind, and are gathered enthusiastically by the crowd below. She leans out further, keeping good hold of the netting a she does, but she leans too far, she loses her grip, and suddenly SLIPS -  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 12

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No! She SCREAMS - and then spins athletically around the hoop smiles. The crowd cheer below.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: It’s what they call entertainment, Mr Glaisher.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Well, I’m not finding it particularly entertaining.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Yes, it requires a sense of humour. Which you seem to..lack. She hangs nonchalantly in the air, her arms outstretched, welcoming the applause, her smile wider still.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, don’t look so sour. The dog. Give me the dog.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: What do you mean give you the dog?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Pass me Posey, Mr. Glaisher.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I’m not handing you the dog. JAMES wrestles with this notion.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Posey, now. Before we lose them. He scrabbles around in the basket for the dog. Eventually he’s able to grab POSEY and passes the dog up her. But as he does, she lets POSEY slip from her grasp. She screams and he hollers out in astonishment - as the d plummets past him, falling towards the earth with a yelp, looks down after it - anguished - and then the dog’s parachute opens. A parachute? The crowd cheer ever louder. She smiles.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 13 She spins round on the hoop and kisses the air extravagan JAMES looks at her - unsure what has happened here, but s he doesn’t like it.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, well done Posey! Well done. She watches as POSEY is caught in NED’s arms below and th breathes in a tremendous breath, she is high on exhilarat She sees JAMES looking up at her. *

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr Glaisher, you are airborne for the first time in your life, I suggest you spend less time frowning at me and more taking in the world we’ve just left. JAMES looks down and suddenly it seems all of London is l out below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1,200ft. Rising 400ft/min. 23C / 73F AMELIA looks at JAMES, she smiles quietly at his astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: (soft) Quite something isn’t she? London. When we’re further up, we’ll be able to see across to Windsor and down to Brighton. With current bearing, we should end up somewhere south of Canterbury. But anything is possible in this weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAMES says nothing. AMELIA looks at him a moment more and then is a hive of energy balancing their equipment. From entertainer to businesswoman in two short breaths.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: It all looks so -

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Insignificant? With one final look down, she pulls herself down to the basket, flashes him a smile and then turns back to her equipment.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Do you take anything seriously? JAMES shakes his head.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 14

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Those people gathered to see an act of science, to witness us break the height record, they didn’t need to see a flying dog.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Still stuck there, are you? AMELIA pulls her sleeves down and starts to take her make off.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I have spent much of my life being laughed at for what I do Miss Wren, I did hope today of all days might prove an exception. He returns to his books. She watches him carefully.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Tell me, what determines your reputation?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: My reputation?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Your standing in the scientific community? JAMES frowns, considering sincerely.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I am aware what reputation means. The papers I’ve written, the discoveries I’ve uncovered.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Your reputation is built on paper. My reputation is built on screams. Those people below came to be entertained. And they - if you didn’t know - are the ones paying for this trip. JAMES looks at her, then shakes his head, as he takes a p of opera-glasses out of a pocket in the side of the baske

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Off to the opera? He ignores her and uses the glasses to look up at the sky the darkening clouds - he frowns, but then dismisses his worry.  10 The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 15

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t try and pretend that cloud isn’t a concern.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I am the scientist. You’re the pilot Miss Wren. Let’s stick to our roles shall we? He looks down at Greenwich Observatory, hundreds of feet below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A younger JAMES GLAISHER is climbing fast up a sloping ro wearing a large shoulder bag. He is being pursued by JOHN TREW.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: JAMES. James.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I will not miss this, John. JAMES opens a window, climbs out of it and is gone.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: For God's sake. JOHN makes a face to himself. And then cursing his better nature, crawls up the roof after his friend. JOHN TREW (CONT’D) It is in the air, we could have stayed on the ground and looked up.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: We must see it from the best vantage point, Johnny. JAMES pulls himself onto the roof. JOHN a few windows behind him, with one more despairing l to the ground, pulls himself after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN lies flat on the roof, panting deeply. Bells can be heard striking in the distance. JAMES turns towards them with a smile.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 16

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: The sky is clear. I predict a clean take-off. Which means in precisely sixteen seconds precisely we should see.... JAMES unpacks his shoulder bag - revealing within it a la telescope and then a stand to place it upon.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: You are aware he might not get off the ground? He fits the telescope into the stand.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Charles Green will get it off the ground. He moves the stand to the very edge of the building. JOHN sees plaster crumble away.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: Maybe not quite so close to the edge of the building.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: John, stop scowling at me. Do I clock the hours I spend helping you pin butterflies to a board?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: Pinning butterflies is not a dangerous pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Five, four, three, two, one. There’s a long pause. JAMES slowly deflates, JOHN looks a his friend with sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: It could be anything. The gas valve ruptured, the silk tore - JAMES smiles as suddenly - clear as a day across London, balloon starts to rise up. JAMES looks at JOHN with the largest of smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: He has rethought his balloon shape. Wider at the top, like a parachute.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 17

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: May I look? JAMES reluctantly lets JOHN look through. JOHN looks intently.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Mr Trew, if you’ve had time enough... JOHN steps away with a smile, JAMES retakes his perch. And then thinks and then lifts the equipment and repositi himself towards the outside of the building.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s broken cloud. He refocuses the telescope.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve lost him. He looks up to the sky. He squints. JOHN TREW looks at hi friend.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: You’1ll get your chance you know. They'll realise your worth.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I think they know what I’m worth well enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAMES GLAISHER stands at a lectern, in front of him assor scientists.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: We know more now about the world around us than we have at any time in history, but still we are limited by our ignorance as to what is truly above us. With the progress we have made in balloon travel here at the Society, pioneered by Charles Green, we could advance meteorology by decades. Analysis of the Earth’s magnetic field, the solar spectrum, knowledge of the dew point, an understanding of oxygenation of the atmosphere...  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 18

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES GREEN
dialogues.text: He wants my balloon! Laughter breaks out again.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: No sir, I want funding for my own expedition into the skies -

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES GREEN
dialogues.text: We are scientists, not fortune tellers! You talk of weather prediction. There’s laughter. JAMES rides over it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Is that not our responsibility as scientists - to bring order to the chaos...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - if we can understand what’s - you are no closer to above us -— predicting the movements of the weather than the movements of a frog in a jar. He makes to walk out of the lecture theatre, others follo

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: With your financial support I believe we are on the precipice of great change - the possibility of advance weather prediction might allow for - He sees them all departing.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please - please - 10c EXT. ROYAL SOCIETY. DAY 10c JAMES stands in the courtyard alone, as snow falls all ar him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James's father, ARTHUR GLAISHER is reading a newspaper article.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: “James Glaisher spoke this week at the Royal Society of his plans to make a science of the weather. -  10Ab 11 The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 19

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I’ve read it, Pa.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: “To the accompaniment of much laughter, he laid out -”

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Arthur. Stop it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: They're wrong, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Many more think you are.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Many didn’t believe Newton.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Oh, James. Newton changed the way we saw the Earth and the planets. You think you can predict when it might rain. JAMES takes the bullet. He holds hard to his dignity. ARTHUR GLAISHER (CONT’D) What they say about you - it doesn’t hurt?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I wish it didn’t hurt you. EXT. WATCH SHOP. DAY 10Ab JAMES walks away from the shop. He looks up back at his father’s window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5,700ft. Rising 400ft/min. 18C / 64F We re-join Wren & Glaisher, high above London, as they dr upward towards the thick cloud bank above them. WREN is dressing herself thoroughly in warm weather gear. sort of precursor to flying leathers. She does so discreetly, and JAMES makes sure to look away. She’s striking, practical and in control - she knows what is coming. JAMES, still in his wool suit, continues to take his measurements.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 20

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Nine minutes and sixteen seconds. Height 5,700 feet. Air temperature, 64 degrees Fahrenheit.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: How delightful. (motioning to her corset) Could you? He awkwardly helps her to undo her corset. She takes it o and puts on her jacket.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should put on your oilskins, Mr Glaisher. Ignoring her, he writes something on a piece of paper. He ties it to a pigeon and lets it go, it flies shakily a and then down.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you attaching to those pigeons?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Our readings.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Oh, so reassuring to know you've contemplated our deaths.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Just - insured against them. AMELIA looks at him, she frowns, amused, but this time sh doesn’t challenge him, she looks up at the dark sky above them.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Cloud ahoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6,100ft. Rising 400ft/min. 15C / 59F The balloon is swallowed by the heavy, still clouds, and AMELIA looks over the edge so the earth disappears from v

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: What more felicitie can fall to creature Than to enjoy delight with libertie,  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 21

dialogues.speaker: PIERRE
dialogues.text: And to be lord of all the workes of Nature, She turns and sees PIERRE with his back to her, looking o at the clouds. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN AND PIERRE
dialogues.text: To raine in th’aire from earth to highest skie, To feed on flowres and weeds of glorious feature. She approaches PIERRE, he turns, and it’s - JAMES.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: To take whatever thing doth please the eye. AMELIA looks at him - astonished. He smiles shyly.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Spenser. The Fate of the Butterfly. One of my favourite poems. AMELIA swallows, dealing with her complicated emotions.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Surprising. Didn’t have you down as a literary man.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Men of science can enjoy words, Miss Wren.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: My husband loved that poem. Beat. JAMES tries to retain his dignity.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I would have liked to have met your husband.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I’m not sure he'd have liked you.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: He disliked people who studied rather than practiced. JAMES takes the dig as he reaches out and feels the air o his fingers. A roll of THUNDER.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 22

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We are still sure this weather will hold - because my instinct tells me

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Instinct has no place in weather prediction.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: - that you’re lying to me.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Every reading I took this morning -

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: And there are no advantages in concealing concerns - we’re trapped here no matter what you say. JAMES thinks and then looks at her. He looks back at his measuring apparatus.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: The air pressure is - changing faster than I anticipated. There is a flash of LIGHTNING - AMELIA turns towards it a JAMES scans the sky - truly concerned now.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Your readings were wrong. We are about to get wet.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Quiet. He holds out a hand. He’s listening for something else. W wait with him - the silence is powerful and oppressive. AMELIA looks at her hands. Moisture is clinging to her gloves. There is another rumble of THUNDER.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: You're discerning how close we are to the storm. JAMES says nothing - clearly panicked, he turns to his equipment and consults numbers in his book. Suddenly the balloon JOLTS. The balloonists grab the side of the baske Then there is calm again. AMELIA looks to the West and th East. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And so it begins.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 23 EXT. SKY. CONTINUOUS -— 13 We’re in a pocket amongst the cumulonimbus clouds. We lin on the churning sky. Lightning illuminates hidden crevices. A rapidly shifting and darkening landscape. We see moving through it - the Mammoth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7,200ft. Rising 400ft/min. 10C / 50F And then we’re back inside the balloon. JAMES is taking readings.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: We need to batten down. He takes out his Spectroscope. He twirls it around. He ma notes in his book. AMELIA WREN (CONT’D) I’m not sure your instruments are much use to us now. JAMES looks at her, and then checks the hygrometer.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are no prizes for obstinacy. James — THUNDER. They both turn towards it.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you won’t listen to me. Listen to that.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Not one of my readings suggested a storm -

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Well that’s what it is, and we’re inside a cumulo, which is precisely where we shouldn’t be. He takes more readings. He’s more skittery now, less focu She sees another flash of LIGHTNING. A roll of THUNDER on seconds later.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 24

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, The Mammoth is not made of conductive material - we won't attract lightning.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: And if we do, the gas keeping us afloat is fifty per cent hydrogen, thirty-five percent methane, so we won’t live long enough for me to point out how wrong you were...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7,600ft. Speed of ascent constantly changing. 9C / 48F Suddenly both balloonists are THROWN to the floor, an agitation in the air causes a WHIRLWIND - which turns the giant balloon three times from the right to the left. There is another SMASH OF LIGHTNING closer to the balloon this time, and with it comes the RAIN. Rain which lashes down and which seems to suggest worse. JAMES returns to his instrumentation, writing down a seri of readings.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Get that equipment put away now -

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: The equipment will give us the information we need to survive this They are THROWN again, violently this time, horrifically time. JAMES is slammed into the side of the basket. AMELIA hauls him to the floor and uses her legs to pincer into position -

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Stay still and keep calm - I need to get us out of here. And then they are THROWN again - and this time JAMES is thrown on top of AMELIA, smashing his head on the pigeon in the process. BLOOD pours from the wound.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: We cannot descend - this may be our one and only opportunity -

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Of course we don’t descend.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 25 JAMES looks at her, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: We don’t?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: There are two ways to break a storm. One is to travel beneath it, the other - to travel above it. The safest way is up. Another fork of LIGHTNING STRIKES. The THUNDER ROARS immediately afterwards. AMELIA looks across at JAMES - a smile spreads across his face.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: The safest way is up?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Who did you think you got ina balloon with? AMELIA smiles and then pulls off her wet and slippy glove and grabs a knife from her small bag and leans over the s of the balloon - seemingly immune to the raging storm - t slice off some bags of ballast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9,000ft. Falling 4000ft/min, then rising 600ft/min. 7C / Then the balloonists hit a pocket of cold air and the bal suddenly DROPS 1000 FEET. This has the effect of sending AMELIA and JAMES and everything that isn’t bound to the basket of the balloon in the air. JAMES’s leg hits the underside of the table o his way up, BREAKING IT and sending his equipment everywh We watch almost in slow motion the detritus float away - gloves arcing gracefully out of the balloon and away. AMELIA and JAMES hit the underside of the balloon, bounce off, and fall back towards the basket again. JAMES lands HARD in the basket, but AMELIA misses the bas clawing desperately at the wicker as she does. JAMES look for her but everything is obscured by the mist. He’s blin

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Amelia! Amelia. AMELIA’s legs dangle helplessly in space. She clings to t rope that holds the grapnel, the rain LASHING around her.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 26 The mist clears and her perilous position becomes very cl She's on the verge of oblivion. Then the mist returns and blindness is intoxicating. JAMES grabs a central rope and reaches out a hand -

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take my hand. Take my hand. He grabs at one of the toggled ropes holding the basket t the hoop, but in quick succession three of the TOGGLES SN and the balloon is massively destabilized, everything tum towards him as the basket falls into a slant. This loosen AMELIA’s grip and she falls further. Screaming as she doe

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I can’t - I can’t get...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Hold on. HOLD ON. He grabs another rope, then quickly ties a rope around hi waist and secures the other end to the hoop above his hea He steels himself - overcomes his fear - and leans out.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: On three. One. Two. They grab hands. They dangle for a moment, him holding her as firmly as he can. And then he starts heaving her back into the balloon. She scrabbles up, gets a foothold. It’s hard. The rain continues to lash their faces. AMELIA manoeuvres way upwards. She lands beside him in the bottom of the basket, both BREATHING DEEPLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9,600ft. Rising 600ft/min, then 1000ft/min. 5c / 41F As the storm buffets around them, AMELIA pulls a ROPE nex JAMES, releasing a sandbag which plummets into the cloud. She pulls another ROPE on her side of the basket: another of ballast FALLS.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Hold tight, it’s not over yet.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 27 They look at each other, clinging on for dear life, as th storm rages around them. There’s a particularly large JOLT and then there’s silenc They both breathe out. The grey mist surrounding them beg to brighten as we start to get wispy definition in the clouds. Then, almost magically, sunlight pours into the basket. T both smile as a golden-tinged blue starts to emerge. A calmness floods both over them and the balloon. AMELIA unties the rope, and they both lie there a little more. Then JAMES stumbles to his feet and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 11,500ft. Rising 1000ft/min. 3C / 37F The basket is tilting at a desperate angle. But the sky - sky bears no scar of what they have just been through. He looks down at the storm, and then up at the tranquil air.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: We rose above it. AMELIA gets to her feet slowly, she looks around herself. looks at the dripping wet balloon, ropes and at the wet p basket.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Well. We mostly did. This is one broken bird. She looks at him, she smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN TREW stands looking through a telescope. He thinks, frowns, and puts the telescope away. CHARLIE approaches.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: May I look through your spyglass Sir?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: There’s nothing to see. I lost them when the storm passed over.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I would like a look all the same Sir. JOHN looks him up and down.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 28

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I won't steal it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: I didn’t presume you would. You have interest in the air?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Don’t you wish to be up there with them?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: I'd be an unnecessary weight.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: All the same... A look of intense sincerity passes across JOHN TREW’s fac

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: Some reach for the stars, and some push others toward them. CHARLIE looks at him like he thinks he’s mad.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I wish I was up there.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: And you're not afraid of the clouds?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Clouds are just water.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: What about the birds that may attack you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: May I look through your eye glass? JOHN TREW smiles, he pulls the eye glass out. We look upwards. Lurching this way and that with CHARLIE’ eyes. We twitch this way and that - looking for something - anything - and then we see something - a speck - CHARLIE (0.S.) (CONT’D) I can see them, Sir. JOHN TREW looks over, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: Not possible.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 29

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I can see them Sir, I can. CHARLIE hollers with joy as we ascend quickly towards a s that becomes a balloon that becomes the Mammoth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13,500ft. Rising 350ft/min. 1C / 34F And we're back in the balloon and looking down, a magnifi sea of cloud lies beneath it, its surface being varied wi endless hills, hillocks, mountain chains and many snow wh masses rising from it. Towering pillars of Cumulonimbus r upwards to the heavens all around them. The balloon is dwarfed by the enormity of the cloudscape. The thunder, now far below them, rumbles beneath the car. JAMES and the equipment are now on the other side of the basket, trying to rebalance and re-angle the basket. AMEL is above him, perilously balancing on the edge of the balloon, lashing a rope from the basket to the hoop in or to re-engineer the broken toggle.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Now pull hard. Hold it. There.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: There?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: There. I believe we’ve - done it. She looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It should keep. She smiles. She bangs on the hoop.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stronger than she looks. She stays on the edge of the basket. She looks out, a str smile on her face. JAMES immediately busies himself reset his equipment.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr Glaisher. We pull up to see JAMES collecting readings.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: James. You will miss it.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 30 She indicates an aureole - a full-circle rainbow to their East. JAMES turns. A myriad of colours that glitters in the light. It’s mesmeric. And reflected in the centre of it, the Mammoth. A ghost balloon with a multi-colored halo. A dazzling sight.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: (awed) An Aureole. Have you...ever seen one? AMELIA nods.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: You haven't.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Only in books. JAMES reaches out almost to touch it. She smiles to see h glee. There’s a long moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I believe you should be checking your instruments, Mr Glaisher. You can’t have taken a good reading in quite some time. JAMES looks at the full-circle rainbow. And then back at

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: You do so enjoy being amused by me.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I am amused by your enjoyment of something that has nothing to do with numbers. JAMES looks out, he smiles. And then he looks down.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Have you noticed? It’s completely silent. There’s a silence. Then JAMES raises his hands in the air HOLLERS LOUDLY. AMELIA laughs.  23 The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 31 He raises his hands and HOLLERS again. JAMES takes a deep breath in. He stands swaying a moment. He HOLLERS a third time. She thinks and then HOLLERS herself. The two look at each other and smile.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cloud ahoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15,250ft. Rising 350ft/min. -2C / 29F The balloon drifts into the upper section of one of the l cumulonimbus columns. They’re surrounded by mist again. And then there’s the sound of a church bell. AMELIA looks around - as if searching for it. Then we hear whispers of voices that transfigure into wor calling to each other. As if by magic, we are surrounded by the crystal clear so of a London street. It’s as if we’re right there.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Would you listen to that?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: But that sounds like -

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Horses. Bells. People. It is the sound of the streets.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: We have flown through a storm and still London follows us. JAMES checks his instruments. A look of delight on his fa He doesn’t see AMELIA’s discombobulation. One voice pierc through the others.

dialogues.speaker: PIERRE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thank you for giving me somewhere I belonged. AMELIA looks down as if desperately searching for it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: The Hygrometer reading is phenomenal. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 32

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I suppose the humid conditions must be conducting the sound. JAMES thinks and then shouts down.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have no interest in you London. Please leave us alone, you damn - ants. She feels dizzy a moment, and slumps to the floor of the basket.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you well?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: It‘ll soon pass. INT. AMELIA’S HOUSE. DAY 24 AMELIA is asleep on a rug beside a deep armchair. A bottl beside her. Posey looks up at her, watching her snore. There is a loud knocking at the door. She ignores it, until it suddenly opens.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I didn’t lock it.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: No. You did not. AMELIA turns and looks at ANTONIA. They look similar. The sisters.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're not dressed.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: And yet I am wearing clothes.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: When was the last time you changed them?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: You break down my door to tell me to wash?

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: When was the last time you opened any curtains?  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 33

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Sunlight ages - I want my furnishings to retain their glow.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: Which ones are glowing? The ones with your food upon them or the ones covered in dirty clothing?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I do not need to see it to know it’s there.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: Well, much as you might enjoy your self-pity, I am not here to freshen anything. Phillip has invited us to a small gathering -

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: No. ANTONIA picks up a glass, she sniffs it. She recoils.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: Amelia....

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I do so hate how you say my name. Like a priest imploring me to confess my sins.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: It’s been two years.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: And that’s time enough?

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: Do you think Pierre would have wanted this? AMELIA turns and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: That is beneath even you.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: (imploring) I‘1l help you change. Come. Sisters together. And then I’11 let you rot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMELIA stands in the middle of a floor.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 34 Around her moves society. And it does seem like all of society is here. The finest gowns, the fiercest laughter, tinkliest conversation. AMELIA looks swallowed up within it.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT FRANCES
dialogues.text: Your sister is proud as punch she pulled you here.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Hello, Auntie.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT FRANCES
dialogues.text: She keeps trying to persuade men to take you onto the floor. POPPY walks past them both, a chiselled man either side o her, hanging on her every word, she turns and grins at AMELIA, who looks back.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: And they refuse her?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT FRANCES
dialogues.text: I think they’re intimidated by you. AUNT FRANCES indicates, ANTONIA is talking to a young man looks over at AMELIA, and then looks away - blushing as h does. AMELIA laughs. AUNT FRANCES (CONT’D) Still, hard to be the woman that provokes fear. AUNT FRANCES touches her niece’s neck, and then moves on the crowds. AMELIA looks over as ANTONIA is talking to another young She looks down at her feet.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You’re the Widow Wren. AMELIA turns to be faced with JAMES.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I dislike that title.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: You’re Miss Wren.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Amelia Wren. And who might you be?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Glaisher. James Glaisher.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 35

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: It was a pleasure to meet you, Mr Glaisher. She nods, she makes to walk on. JAMES calls after her desperately.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: What brings you here?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: The selfish needs of a sister. You?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: The mercenary needs of a friend - he needed accompanying to his “romance” — He indicates across the hall, a handsome man dancing stra backed with a woman.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She is apparently worth thousands of pounds a year. I am trapped here, just as you.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Well, we needn’t trap each other. She makes to walk on. But JAMES is still not letting her

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I am a scientist, an astronomer, a meteorologist, and —-

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: A scientist, an astronomer and a what?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: A meteorologist. I believe weather can be predicted. AMELIA looks disbelievingly at him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need to make studies of the air and I need to be in the air She turns and nods and makes to walk away. JAMES pursues

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - and I need you to take me. AMELIA steps back - surprised. There’s a pause.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Do you even have a balloon?  26 The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 36

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Not yet, no.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: So you make an invitation to me when it is I should be inviting you?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I need us to - I need you to fly us higher than anyone has ever travelled before. AMELIA considers. She looks up, she looks at JAMES, she s her sister circling another man.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Dance with me.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Dance with you?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Dance with me and we may converse more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMELIA and JAMES are now turning around the dance floor. Around them others move elegantly, AMELIA is determined n to, slipping her feet into the wrong place, kicking her h back in the wrong manner. Not ostentatiously, if it weren for the fact that we’re studying her we wouldn’t notice, it’s there. Yes, even in dance she finds small ways to rebel.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I presume there is a game you’re playing with others in the room -

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: You think I’m trying to make another jealous? You’re not that handsome.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Every man in this room is petrified to be seen talking to you, let alone dancing with you. No, your game is with another. Those words hurt AMELIA, but she won’t let them show. She looks across, she sees ANTONIA, who is watching her with careful smile.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 37

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: You're clever.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Merely observant.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Or presumptuous. And equally, there are certain things - if I may - that I feel safe in presuming about you. JAMES says nothing, but is that fear on his face?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Perhaps that you don’t have an invitation for tonight’s events. Would that be a fair presumption?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: On what basis do you make that assumption?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Your suit is two years out of fashion, your shoes abominable, your dancing ridiculous, I'm leading, you are not, and, finally, because this man clearly doesn’t know you at all. She has steered them to the handsome man he claimed he wa here with. She spins him to a stop in front of him. JAMES looks at the man, who frowns back. His secret has b exposed cruelly. But AMELIA doesn’t care.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you for the dance. She disconnects from him. He pulls her back towards him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I didn’t realise appearances were so important to you. I’m sorry they do not live up to your society standard.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I don’t care what shoes you wear. I care that you’re lying to me.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 38

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: It will be your balloon. All I want is to help with the design and be given the freedom to undertake the experiments that -

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I am not a coachman for hire.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Good. I’m looking for a fellow scientist. To understand the weather is to understand how to make ships and sailors safer, farms more productive. We can prepare ourselves and our world for floods, drought, famines. He can see he’s getting to her. She opens her mouth to sp and then pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to rewrite the rules of the air, Miss Wren, and I need your help. So will you? Help me? We close on AMELIA’s face. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMELIA is examining a balloon as it is partially inflated ANTONIA walks up behind her, dragging her children behind her.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: You're punishing me. AMELIA turns and frowns at ANTONIA, and looks particularl surprised to see her children.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I’m not sure a factory full of flammable gasses is the safest place for children -

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: You're punishing me for dragging you to that ridiculous evening.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I'm grateful to you for dragging me to that ridiculous evening, I would not have made the acquaintance of Mr Glaisher otherwise. Now, girls, I believe we have some macaroons somewhere -  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 39

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: And if that is not proof of punishing me then I don’t know what is.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Not here. AMELIA walks away from the balloon, past a selection of baskets being woven to her specifics, she doesn’t want th conversation to happen in front of the engineers. She wal quickly, and ANTONIA walks quickly beside her. ANTONIA’s children have to fight to keep up with them both.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: I hated you going in the air with Pierre, but why you would go up on your own - I can’t even -

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: With Mr Glaisher.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: You are my only sister, I do not wish to lose you to any more foolishness.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: You'd rather I found a man prepared to marry me, to devote myself to.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: I'd rather you'd find a way to make yourself happy rather than the pursuit of frivolous history making. You can’t just fly away from your problems! You have to face them here - on earth - with the rest of us. AMELIA pushes their way into a corner where reams of mate lie ready for stitching.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Antonia, I believe there are answers in the sky -

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: Let somebody else find them.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Pierre believed it too - and this Mr Glaisher -

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: - sounds barely capable of anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 40

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: But I am capable - I ama really good aeronaut - and I want to use what I’m good at -

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: You are a highly accomplished woman. You could be good at so many things. You could have the most beautiful life amongst society - if only you’d try.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: And if that isn’t what I want?

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: Then you have to learn to want it. Fight the important battles, so you may find a life you can be proud of.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Up there - it’s where I’ve found the greatest happiness. ANTONIA looks at her sister, cold.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: He was the happiness, not the damn balloon. (she calls out) Come on girls, we're late for lunch. The words sink into AMELIA’s face as she watches her sist pull her children from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18,600ft. Rising 400ft/min. -4C / 25F We rejoin the aeronauts as they soar higher. They are sit together on the floor of the balloon. JAMES has assembled instruments on top of the campaign chest, and is using th top of his ruined table to write on. The clouds roll in their glittering masses beneath them a the balloon throws a large shadow on this heap of clouds. JAMES'’s suit is wet through and he is cold - the only th preventing hypothermia is the fierce sun - which is keepi him moderately heated (and causing his clothes to steam).

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Have you been up this high before?  28 The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 4l

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Only once.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: With Pierre? She says nothing. JAMES looks at her face, she looks overwhelmed. There’s a silence. JAMES is unsure how to break the silen

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have time enough for it, why don’t you tell me about him? AMELIA takes a swab from a pocket in the side of the bask

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Ashamed as I am to not stick to your conversational schedule, I have nothing to tell. Does your forehead not hurt?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I can’t feel it. I didn’t mean to - what happened to you - I didn’t mean to make light of it. AMELIA nods, and then starts to clean his cut. He lets he

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: It will heal. (beat) You won’t have a scar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19,400ft. Rising 500ft/min. 0C / 32F As AMELIA tends to JAMES’ wound, a YELLOW BUTTERFLY flutt past them and lands on a piece of JAMES’ equipment. They look at it in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: At this height?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: That's exactly what I was thinking. Then another YELLOW BUTTERFLY floats past. Soon they are surrounded by a swarm of butterflies, brilliant yellow against the clear blue sky. It is a sight to behold.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He was right! The fool was right!  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 42 AMELIA stands watching the butterflies - her emotion palpable. JAMES laughs in delight, as a BUTTERFLY lands on his head and then another on AMELIA’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of all the amazing things - My friend John Trew - he’s made study of them. He theorised - beyond the birds - an air current on which only the insects travel... I never believed him and I certainly didn’t think we’d prove him right. The butterfly on his head flies away. He smiles reaches o hand and gently lifts the butterfly from her arm. This fe like a new intimacy. We lean into that moment and then th both flick it away.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: They are wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Where are they heading, do you think?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Perhaps they trust the wind to decide. He smiles at her, she smiles back, and then her expressio changes. She reaches out her hand and places it within the butterflies.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He'd have liked these. Pierre. They dance around her and away. She turns and watch them Then she turns back to JAMES, with tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My husband was the bravest man I knew. He saw possibilities others could not, but his most enduring quality was a deep and true love for the beauty of the world. She waits a moment. He looks at her.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 43

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. Others would have pushed me further. Thank you for not.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I cannot quantify what you lost. She looks at him a moment more.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: No. You can’t. Return to your instruments, Mr Glaisher. James. JAMES looks at her a moment more, unsure whether to say anything else. She looks back, proud but with a vulnerabi we haven't seen before. AMELIA WREN (CONT’D) I said, return to your instruments -

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I shall. He does, and then he looks back at her, and then he retur to his instruments. INT. AMELIA’S HOUSE. NIGHT 53 AMELIA is sitting on her own. A look on her face of pure contemplation. And contemplation for her is pain. She looks over a collection of newspaper clippings; a his of her past life in the air. Headlines saying ‘BELLE OF T BALLOON!” A wedding picture of her and Pierre. And an art about Pierre’s death in a balloon accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMELIA’s feet click to the sound of scandal. This is a me only establishment. Not that any of the men she passes ha the confidence to say so. AMELIA knows she’s breaking the rules and is very much enjoying doing so.

dialogues.speaker: AIRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Wren isn’t it? Amelia Wren? AMELIA turns to see AIRY walking with CHARLES GREEN.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I’m looking for James Glaisher -  38 The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 44

dialogues.speaker: AIRY
dialogues.text: You are very welcome to wait outside while we fetch him to you. We have a policy you see about the fairer sex and -

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Then I’1l find him myself. She nods at CHARLES.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lovely to see you again Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN TREW is staring at a watch. JAMES is anxiously packing the crate we will later see on board the Mammoth. We’re close on him to see the speed an precision with which he works, his hands a flurry through instruments.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: Come on James, imagine you’re hurtling toward the ground.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Time?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: Seventeen seconds. Hurry man, your equipment is going to be destroyed. He finishes fitting the final pieces.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TREW
dialogues.text: Twenty six seconds. Well done.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: And you thought I couldn’t break thirty. Amelia enters.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: My senses deserted me - JAMES stands up.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Miss Wren, this is an honour -  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 45

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I do not wish to abandon you but -

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: May I give you a tour -

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I’m afraid I must. There’s a silence.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Abandon me? JAMES keeps himself under control, but only just.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The build is already under way. The largest balloon ever on order...

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I don’t want to climb inside the balloon, Mr Glaisher. I don’t want to climb into a balloon ever again. JAMES is heartbroken. And angry.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: No. No. This is unacceptable - a vast amount of money has already been spent -

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I am sorry Sir, I’ve made my decision. She walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAMES GLAISHER enters the shop, he stands unsure.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Hello Ma.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL GLAISHER
dialogues.text: The wanderer returns. You were due last week.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m sorry. I’ve been busy.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Yes. We’ve been reading all about you in the newspaper. There’s a silence. JAMES can’t meet her eyes.  56 The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 46

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of all the people, James. Women don’t belong in balloons, on show - and she makes such a show of herself. Your reputation risks ruin.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Well, you’ll be pleased to hear that the expedition is off, Ma. ETHEL says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But it was her who did not want to risk flight with me. Is he upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL GLAISHER
dialogues.text: He had a fall - I don’t know quite what caused it - but he is not -

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: It’s got worse?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL GLAISHER
dialogues.text: It comes and goes. Tread carefully with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAMES enters a room. ARTHUR is sitting reading. A brass telescope sits in the corner of the room.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Hard at it. ARTHUR looks up. He looks petrified.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Ethel! Ethel!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Pa. Pa. It’s me. James.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Ethel? Ethel!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Ma knows I’m here. Remember, your son, I’m your son.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: My son is ten years old.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I got older.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 47 ARTHUR looks at him carefully, JAMES stands under the lig so he might examine him. His face softens. JAMES walks ov to the telescope.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What have you been looking at?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Get away from that. JAMES peers through the telescope.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Pallas. You’re looking at Pallas.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: No. Juno.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: You're looking at Juno? You can’t be. The correlation is all wrong. ARTHUR smiles. He’s playing a game they both remember.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: You're entirely right, it’s not Juno, it’s Vesta. JAMES smiles - he looks through the telescope.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: You're playing games with me old man. ARTHUR joins him at the window. He takes out a pair of op glasses from his day coat, we recognise them as the pair the balloon.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Of course I’m looking at Pallas. Good spotting. JAMES looks up at his Father.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Please don’t pretend you can see anything through those.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: You may have moved on to grander things James, but I...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Pa... ARTHUR snorts with laughter. JAMES smiles. He leans down through the telescope. ARTHUR peers up through the opera glasses behind him.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 48

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: These were the glasses I taught you to stargaze through, they are quite sufficient, for some - work...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: You've lined her up well. A good sighting. ARTHUR looks closely at JAMES. Fighting his mind.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Your trip. You’re taking a trip. In a balloon.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: To see the stars.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I’m trying to.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I used to dream of taking my bed sheet, catching a gust of wind and dancing in a parachute amongst the stars.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I know you did. You told me.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: There is nothing more mysterious, nor more beautiful, than the stars in the sky. They look up at the sky, and see something impossible - a tiny, faraway man floating under a bedsheet, dancing amon the stars. Arthur looks at JAMES. We see his mind fade fr him. ARTHUR GLAISHER (CONT’D) What are you doing in here?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: You know the rules. Not in my room. Now, you step away from the spy glass. It’s very valuable James.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I know, I bought it for you -  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 49

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL GLAISHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He’s tired. Probably best not to overdo it. JAMES turns to his Mother. Who is standing in the door.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Thank you. Can you get this boy out of here?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Of course. She smiles at JAMES.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Leave it when you’re on the up, eh? JAMES nods. And then leans down and kisses his Father.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: See you next week, Pa. He makes for the door, his Dad pats his arm.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: James. James! JAMES turns towards him. He holds out the opera glasses. gives them to him. ARTHUR GLAISHER (CONT’D) For your trip. Prove them wrong. Prove me wrong. JAMES nods. Deeply moved.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Thank you. Next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAMES walks quickly from the shop, his pain clear. He looks up at the sky, as if seeing it for the first tim and then pulls his coat tight around him and walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLES GREEN and AIRY are walking fast through the colum at the front of the Royal Society. JAMES catches up with them.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Mr Green.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 50

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES GREEN
dialogues.text: If it isn’t Mr Glaisher, the weather sleuth.

dialogues.speaker: AIRY
dialogues.text: I believe he prefers to be described as a meteorologist Charles.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES GREEN
dialogues.text: Of course he does, well, best of luck with it. He walks on.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Sir, as you know I cannot attract the funds that I need to fly.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES GREEN
dialogues.text: It is an expensive preoccupation.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: And I've heard you're looking to make another balloon flight.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES GREEN
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I would like the opportunity to be your second. You know I can’t promise funds but I will prove a willing accomplice, and I do have ideas of how to increase the level of hydrogen in the coal gas - and I think it might be your unlocking Sir. You might finally be able to break the height record. CHARLES GREEN walks indignantly up to him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES GREEN
dialogues.text: ‘Finally’ break? I did not realise my attempts were such a bore.

dialogues.speaker: AIRY
dialogues.text: They’re not. Of course they’re not.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES GREEN
dialogues.text: Have you ever even been in a balloon?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I have studied them extensively.  33 The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 51

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES GREEN
dialogues.text: Do you have any experience of frostbite, low air pressure, the mind-altering effects of a lack of oxygen on the brain -

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: How else does one learn but by partaking -

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES GREEN
dialogues.text: Exactly what I need in a second, a theorist who knows nothing of the true dangers of the air. JAMES has nothing to reply to that. CHARLES GREEN (CONT’D) Find another madman to get ina balloon with. Perhaps the French. Or better yet - give up! He laughs, and walks away. JAMES looks after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22,300ft. Rising 600ft/min. -6C / 21F The balloon is now coated in a thin layer of ice. JAMES is watching his dials intently.
AMELIA is distractedly checking the thermometers.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Do you have faith in these thermometers?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: If so, we’re at 21 degrees and that is...cold.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: 22,500. Would you note the temperature down?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: You'd trust me to write in your book? I’m honoured.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 52 She writes in his book, looking at him all the time. Fina she looks up, meeting his knowing look.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have we slowed? Are we not at 22,600.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: So you are interested. Yes. We have passed 22,600.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: You’re insufferable.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: You're excited. She turns and watches the dial with him.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: And that is 22,700.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The French are under attack. History will be rewritten.
They both watch the dial in silence.
He looks at her, quite overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: And now we are higher than any man or any woman has ever been. She looks at him, he smiles, she smiles. He looks around himself, his eyes full of emotion. She looks around herself, as overwhelmed as he is. There’s a perfect silence. The perfect silence of achievement. Of doing something greater than you ever felt possible. And it’s combined with a perfect hollowness for them both He looks back at the dial, it now says 23,300. He looks at her. She looks back at him. He reaches out a hand. She takes it. She shakes it.  34 The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 53

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Thank you for taking me up in your balloon, Mr Glaisher.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Thank you for taking me up in your balloon, Miss Wren. They look at each other for a moment. And then JAMES looks out at the world around them. He looks up. He looks down. She just watches him. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: It doesn’t feel different at all does it? You’re disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: On the contrary, this is the moment I’ve waited for my entire life.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Yes. I rather suspect I’ve been waiting for it too. There’s a moment’s pause. Then he goes over to the pigeon box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
