dialogues.text: 23,500ft. Rising 600ft/min. -7C / 19F JAMES writes something on a piece of paper. He ties it to a pigeon and lets it go, it flies shakily a and then down.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: (darkly) Tell me when we land if I deserve your thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: You deserve my thanks. The sand falls away beneath them before being whipped off the wind. 54 EXT. AMELIA’S HOUSE. NIGHT 54 AMELIA opens her front door. JOHN TREW is standing on the other side. Her face falls.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I was busy elsewhere.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 71

dialogues.text: Your readings Sir. JAMES looks at her. He smiles. He draws up his legs. He groggily gets to his feet. He takes his pencil, and leaning against the internal rop he begins to take readings.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I lost my gloves at some - I lost my gloves. JAMES opens one of his boxes. He pulls out a bottle of brandy.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 72

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Yes. Well. A scientist is nothing without his equipment. He smiles. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold them out.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: This is going to hurt. AMELIA looks at him. She holds out her hands. JAMES pours brandy over the top of them. This stings. She grits her t to the pain.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Better?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Worse.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you did for me up there but I have no doubt it was a great act. He takes her hands in his.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your poor hands. He rubs them gently. It’s beautiful. She looks up at him. He looks back. It begins to snow. He looks around at the snow falling all around them. He grins at her. She smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: And now snow, as if we haven't had enough.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 73

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: It will pass. She smiles again. He takes out a sample glass. He catches the snowdrops. Sh looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Possibly interesting to analyse the melt water. She nods. And then she picks up a glass and tries to catc them too. He laughs. She does too. The two of them continue in their complicity. And it is beautiful. And then AMELIA looks back at JAMES, a strange smile on h face. JAMES watches as snow flakes land on her shoulders, cheeks, her eyelashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19,500ft. Falling 2500ft/min. -5C / 23F The two sit - battered to within an inch of their lives, exhausted and as broken as the basket that holds them. There’s an almost perfect silence between them as they wa the snow fall around them as the balloon descends.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: They say that ballooning is about going up, but I’ve always enjoyed the descent just as much. The feeling of the world coming back to you. She looks at JAMES.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And we've returned with important science, am I right?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: We have.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: My sister wanted to know why I would fly in a balloon again. I think it was because I wanted - all that I knew - all that he taught me - all that I lost - to be for something.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 74 JAMES thinks, desperate to give her the meaning.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: It seems the air gets colder the closer we rise to the sun. The humidity gets less dense despite us floating through clouds, which is also odd. There is a clear lack of oxygen at the upper reaches -—

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: That’s not what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Newton said - “we build too many walls and -”

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I don’t want to hear from Newton, I want to hear from you. JAMES thinks deeply.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: All my life, I’ve found comfort in science. It helps give meaning to the many things we cannot control... Brings a degree of order to the chaos that surrounds us. But whilst we may be able to explain the science behind an aureole, or the falling snow, it is not possible to account for its beauty. No amount of data could have helped me predict that the only person who could have taken us to the heights we reached today - was you. Together, we have brought the stars closer. This line penetrates deep. AMELIA softly smiles.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: We have brought the stars closer. AMELIA sits for a moment. Then she looks up. We watch her so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16,000ft. Falling 3500ft/min. -1C / 30F She looks at the snow, she frowns. The snow is floating around them, neither moving down nor  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 75 She checks a gauge. She looks up at the balloon.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Do you notice something about the snow?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: It’s hovering. It’s static. JAMES looks at it, she sees she’s right.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: That is strange - what might -

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: We might, if we were travelling at the same speed as it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: The same speed as - snow? AMELIA looks up at the balloon. She frowns. She looks dow her uncovered shoe.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: The gas, it’s still escaping, this - combined with the decrease in pressure means -— She grabs the valve line and pulls hard.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: - the balloon is collapsing.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Help me. Pull. The balloon comes out of the cloud. He grabs the valve li with her and together they tug hard. Her boot is dislodged and falls down hard through the interior of the balloon, it lands with a thud in the bask

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: What on earth was that?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: My shoe. Probably best not to question it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: But that was - if your shoe was up there that means...  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 76

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: We need to lose weight. A lot of weight. She takes out a knife and starts to try and cut at the ballast. But her hands won’t allow her. JAMES takes the k from her. He cuts it quickly and throws it.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The chest! They throw the chest out together. She tries to take her off but her hands won’t work

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jackets! JAMES throws off his heavy jacket and then starts throwin out his instruments. He stops - he looks at his pocket wa and then his glasses. He throws out the watch and then lo at the glasses. He keeps them in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: (full of decisiveness) Climb up into the hoop. Do it now. Quickly. AMELIA looks at him, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The car. We lose the basket. AMELIA looks at him and then the fast approaching ground.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is the heaviest weight. It’s our only option. JAMES climbs into the hoop, but he can’t do it with the glasses in his hand, he throws them over, shutting his ey for a moment, and then clambers up. He holds down a hand help AMELIA inside, she frowns at him and climbs inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7,500ft. Falling 4,500ft/min. 5C / 41F JAMES lays down on the hoop, wrapping his legs round it t secure himself. He leans down and cuts one of the ropes f the hoop to the basket. It pings away. The basket LURCHES from side to side as the weight distribution changes. AMELIA barely manages to stop herse from falling. She rights herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 77

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Quickly! JAMES shuffles on and cuts the next rope. And then the ne The basket now hangs precariously, held by a single rope.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: James! He slashes at the rope but doesn’t manage to sever it. The basket swings mightily underneath them, causing the balloon to lurch at an uncomfortable angle.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Ready? She nods. He leans in and slashes again and the basket fa away from under them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2,500ft. Falling 2000ft/min. 15C / 59F It hurtles down towards the ground. Their descent slows. JAMES and AMELIA are still clinging AMELIA looks up and then down desperately.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: It’s not enough. We’re still too fast.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: It will be enough.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I was ever meant to survive this. JAMES looks at her, horrified to hear this. And then he realises why she’s telling him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Amelia, what are you doing? No. She pulls herself up onto the hoop and prepares to jump. JAMES desperately looks up, he sees the balloon flapping. thought occurs.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Amelia. Bed sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62 The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 78

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Bed sheets? JAMES looks up, a smile on his face now.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: We sever the cord that holds the balloon in shape, the silk will be sucked up to the top of the netting, and act as a parachute.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: It won't work.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I will not return alone. It will be both of us, or neither of us. AMELIA looks at him with a startled smile and then begins wrap her arms and legs in amongst the ropes. The descent is getting really fast now. The envelope of t balloon is almost entirely collapsed. The noise is overwhelming, everything is overwhelming. He smiles at her, thinks, shuts his eyes and then cuts th cord. And the balloon is free -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 800ft. Falling 1000ft/min. 20C / 68F The material flaps open - and spreads - and they are yank upwards - both shouting out in pain as they are violently wrenched by the ropes. They look at each other, has it worked? It looks like it has. The parachute is holding and they a floating downwards. JAMES looks up astonished. The ground comes at them rapidly: the wind is carrying th at quite some speed and it whips the balloon through the fields. JAMES looks at AMELIA - a final moment of connection - he smiles and then they smash hard into a copse of trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We travel fast and brutally through it. The ring snaps and JAMES is thrown off.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 79 But we stay with AMELIA who clings on for dear life to he partial parachute as the balloon is torn through hedges. And then she’s free of the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The balloon now acts like a sail and drags Wren across th ground spitting up stones and debris as it goes. It hits the ground and bounces up again. It flies for a moment more. We can almost feel the rush o the wind. Then it hits the ground savagely again. She loses consciousness. Her seemingly lifeless body is dragged further across the ground a further ten - fifteen - feet. And then - eventua the balloon comes to a standstill. And there’s silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMELIA opens her eyes. Her skin is battered, bloodied and bruised. She closes her eyes again. And then she opens them again. She looks around.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: James? James? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: She stops and listens. And then, faintly, in the distance

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Amelia! She laughs. They’ve made it. Then she struggles to her fe and hobbles towards James. He’s crawling on his hands and knees, clearly in pain.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: James.  65alt 66 The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 80

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I was just coming to find you.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Not very quickly, it seems. * Can you stand? *

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: I'd rather not.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: And if I help you....

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Then I will stand. She smiles and helps him up. They look around for a momen and then - slowly - begin to walk across the field. *

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was estimated that we rose to a height of 37,000 feet that day - 5 miles high. INT. ARTHUR GLAISHER’S BEDROOM - DAY 65alt * ARTHUR GLAISHER lies in bed, while ETHEL reads from a cop The Times.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL GLAISHER
dialogues.text: “Two aeronauts have been nearer, by some miles, to the moon and stars than all the race of man before them...”

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR GLAISHER
dialogues.text: Our boy. * ARTHUR squeezes ETHEL’S hand. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAMES is delivering a report on his record breaking ballo ascent. JOHN TREW looks on proudly. *

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: James Glaisher’s meticulous * recording of data led to the * discovery that the atmosphere has * different layers within it that *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: govern our weather.  67 68 The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 81

dialogues.speaker: JAMES GLAISHER
dialogues.text: The fact that we were able to come back at all to present this is due to some luck and Amelia Wren’s courageous flying. And so, we tell our story not for the purposes of pleasure, but for the advancement of knowledge and the good of us all. Thank you. The members of the Royal Society begin to rise and start clap, until the whole room is full with the sound of applause.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He was elected head of the Meteorological Society 5 years later. CHARLES GREEN is still sat as the people around him appla He reluctantly gets to his feet and, aware of the people around him, puts his hands together forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMELIA is with ANTONIA and ANTONIA’S DAUGHTERS, running u wet and windy hillside. The girls are carrying kites. Des the weather, everyone’s laughing.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My own discovery was more personal - I found my way back into the world again.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA WREN
dialogues.text: Come on! I’ve flown in worse weather than this. We’ll make pilots of you yet.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: We won’t!!

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We took to the skies in the name of discovery, to find something new. To change the world. But you don’t change the world simply by looking at it. You change it by living in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the basket, JAMES silently takes his measurements and AMELIA pilots the balloon. JAMES looks up for a moment to take in the beauty that surrounds him. He makes eye conta with AMELIA. She holds his look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 82

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We fly not only for ourselves, but to inspire those who come after us. We cut wide to see the balloon sailing up and away, silhouetted against the setting sun.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Look up. The sky lies open. CREDITS.
